topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open teases key ideas: selective user feedback, CEO time allocation, Rahul’s time-tracking method, and his view that “virality” is mostly word of mouth. Lenny introduces Rahul and previews major topics for the episode.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Eppo (experimentation/A-B testing) and Fundrise (real estate investing).

topics.title: Rapportive acquisition and pivotal career lessons
topics.summary: Rahul recounts building Rapportive, scaling to millions, and selling to LinkedIn. He explains why the acquisition was pivotal—especially learning growth principles from LinkedIn’s head of Growth and gaining resources to “swing for the fences.”

topics.title: Virality myth: mechanics vs word of mouth
topics.summary: Rahul shares LinkedIn’s insight that sustained viral factor >1 is rare; even famous products peak below 1. The real driver is unmeasurable word of mouth—users spontaneously recommending the product.

topics.title: Whales, referrals, and making email collaborative
topics.summary: They discuss “whales” who drive outsized referrals and how incentives differ for individuals vs teams. Rahul explains Superhuman’s shift toward multiplayer/collaborative email (Superhuman 2.0) to enable organic team adoption.

topics.title: Baking remarkableness into company values
topics.summary: Rahul describes how Superhuman encodes growth drivers into values: create delight, deliver remarkable quality, and build the extraordinary. The idea is that “remarkable” products naturally generate sharing and attention.

topics.title: Diagnosing slowdown: market widening vs deepening
topics.summary: Rahul breaks down perceived product-velocity slowdown into unavoidable vs avoidable causes. Unavoidable: investing in hard platform expansion (iOS/Android/Outlook/etc.) reduces visible improvements for existing users while building a moat.

topics.title: Org redesign to regain speed and focus
topics.summary: Avoidable slowdown came from a conventional exec-heavy structure that consumed Rahul’s time. He hired a president, reduced direct reports from ~8 to 2, and shifted his time from ~6–7% to ~60–70% on product/design/tech/marketing.

topics.title: Switch log time tracking and context switching
topics.summary: Rahul explains his “Switch log”: DM’ing an assistant/Slackbot with a tag each time he changes tasks to capture real work vs calendar intent. They discuss context switching, attention, and using lightweight logging to audit where time truly goes.

topics.title: Transcendental meditation for performance and creativity
topics.summary: Rahul shares his TM routine (20 minutes + rest, twice daily) and why it’s non-negotiable. He describes benefits over time: improved focus, creativity, and expressiveness, plus advice to learn with a coach (Peak Leadership Institute).

topics.title: President role as operational co-founder substitute
topics.summary: Rahul details what the president owns: exec-team management, operations, and strategic thought partnership across AI, margins, product roadmap, and hiring geography. He frames it as a “grown-up co-founder” role that restores founder leverage.

topics.title: Attention to detail: funding story and typography
topics.summary: Rahul recounts early Superhuman fundraising with Ed Sim and then dives into why Superhuman chose (and modified) Adelle Sans—optimizing for beauty, tone flexibility, reading speed, and email-address rendering. The segment highlights craft as a product differentiator.

topics.title: Craft vs speed: when polish matters pre-launch
topics.summary: They discuss the tradeoff between launching early and ensuring reliability, arguing it depends on market dynamics and product criticality. Rahul uses a Mailbox failure story to show why mission-critical tools like email can’t ship half-baked.

topics.title: Positioning Superhuman around speed
topics.summary: Rahul explains how he chose “speed” as Superhuman’s core position: validated via customer interviews, uniqueness/availability, fit with competing against incumbents, and the “cocktail party test.” Speed became the memorable wedge for adoption.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor segment featuring OneSchema and its new FileFeeds product for building CSV-based integrations quickly and reliably.

topics.title: Manual concierge onboarding teaser
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Superhuman’s contrarian approach of mandatory 1:1 onboarding for every new user and asks how far it scaled. Rahul begins to explain why it was essential early on, ending mid-thought as the excerpt cuts off.
